text: [Music]
hello and welcome to our virtual black hat presentation entitled repurposing neural networks to generate
synthetic media for information operations my name is phil tully and i'll be joined later in this slide deck by my colleague
lee foster we work together at fireeye where i'm a staff data scientist on fire ice data
science team and lee is the senior manager of information operations in fireeye's threat intelligence group
for a bit of background about myself i've been at fireeye for two years and i've been working at the intersection of cyber security and machine learning
for over five years in a previous academic life i earned my doctorate in computational neuroscience
and nowadays i perform research and development on fire's malware and intel product offerings
lee and his team of intel analysts specialize in identifying cyber driven nation state influence campaigns online
he holds a master's degree in political science a second in intelligence and international security
and is currently pursuing a third masters in analytics so some quick bookkeeping to start out
at first in this presentation we're going to try to convince you that open source pre-trained machine learning models can
be leveraged to generate custom synthetic media for malicious purposes after introducing some core background
material i'll dive into three successive proof of concepts for how this can be accomplished today in the text image and audio domains i'm
going to channel the three wise monkeys and organize these experiments into three sections see no evil hear no evil and speak no
evil i'll demonstrate how to fine-tune pre-trained natural language processing computer vision
and text-to-speech neural networks in order to generate customizable synthetic media
lee will then wargame out these capabilities in the context of social media driven information operations or io and assess
the challenges underlying detection attribution and response in scenarios where actors can anonymously generate
and distribute credible fake content we'll start off with some background
initial material and for starters it's worth pointing out that synthetic media is by no means a new
development methods for manipulating media for specific agendas are as old as the media themselves
you'll see some of the more famous examples illustrated here including when the chief of the soviet
secret police was photographed walking alongside joseph stalin before being retouched out of an
official press photo after he himself was arrested and executed during the great purge
an image of the pyramids was altered to fit the cover of national geographic magazine shifting two of them closer together to
emphasize their size digital graphic after effects like this became prominent with the advent of photoshop
now fast forward to 2016 where carefully crafted social media messages were being posted across several platforms
in order to disrupt public discourse and influence online opinion leading up to the us presidential election
then later in the 2010s the term deep fake was coined there were several viral deep fakes
including one targeting mark zuckerberg screenshotted here that was designed to be a warning about the future of digital
manipulation deep pick videos including techniques like face swapping and lip syncing are
concerning in the long term our talk will focus on more basic and arguably more believable synthetic media
generation advancements including in the text image and audio domains we'll provide evidence later in the talk how some of
these are already being leveraged as part of i o campaigns today social media has greased the wheels for
this type of activity by providing anonymity immediate global reach and the ability to go viral
rife data disclosure and most importantly a seamless way to share content publicly
the low-hanging fruit nature of this threat environment was illustrated by previous work i was part of led by john seymour
four years ago at black cat we demonstrated how to generate credible synthetic texts to manipulate social
media users for the purpose of simulated fishing attacks the snapper bot was shown to combine the
best best of both worlds the shotgun approach of fishing think nigerian print scams that take little
effort and have relatively low success rates and the more targeted approach of spearfishing that takes additional
upfront research effort but typically pays off in terms of higher success rates by seating a machine learning model with
content read off the target's twitter timeline and generating text pertaining to their recent tweet history
then simulating this at scale we could get click-throughs more often and with less effort compared with humans
all due to machine learning such generative machine learning models can also be used for good too
a few examples covered by the popular press are shown here on the left they can be trained to mimic the voices
of those with degenerative speech or language disorders allowing people to synthesize words in their own voice well after it's been
lost museums have brought dead artists back to life using machine learning models to interact with visitors in compelling
educational new ways and activists can narrate their own stories more safely by superimposing fabricated faces over
videos of themselves allowing viewers to more and more easily empathize without exposing anyone's
identities but as these capabilities proliferate there are just as many if not more
misuse cases that have arisen in the real world a few of those are called out here on the left including one case in which a
scammer used an artificially generated voice of an executive's boss to fool the executive into handing over two hundred
and forty thousand dollars another in which deep fakers created disturbingly realistic porno videos of
women using photos of them involuntarily scraped from the internet and the last one where a computer vision
model was used to generate fake profile pictures for a linkedin persona that socially engineered so um senior
government officials so there's existing evidence showing that machine learning can be used to
generate synthetic media for evil purposes and in this talk we want to focus on one specific technical methodology that's
been that's drastically reduced the amount of time and effort involved in making this happen
transfer learning is a paradigm for machine learning in which we start from a large generic model that's been pre-trained for an initial task where
copious data is available we then leverage the model's acquired knowledge to train it further on a different
smaller data set so that it excels at a subsequent related task this process of training the model
further is referred to as fine tuning which typically requires less resources compared to training it from scratch
this is illustrated in the diagram on the left normally when there are two separate tasks that need to be solved
a data scientist has to wrangle two separate data sets and train two separate models in this example a classifier on the left
and a regressor on the right independently in order to ship them both to production and transfer learning shortcuts this
process if task 1 is related to task 2 in a way that task two can benefit from the learned representations
of task one then we can actually use the neural network train to perform task one as a starting point for task two all of
our while requiring significantly less initial data for test two you can think of this in more relatable
terms if i'm a professional tennis player i don't need to completely relearn how to swing a racket in order to excel at
badminton in a technical sense this fine tuning can be accomplished in several ways
by lowering or freezing learning rates by making architectural modifications to the network or by
only allowing updates in specific weights or layers transfer learning works because early layers produce features that capture
general attributes of the training data set whereas later layers capture properties of the task it's being uh trained on
as such a common fine-tuning approach simply involves freezing the early layers from the pre-trained model
and retraining just the last layer using a small data set for a new task this is computationally much easier than
training a new model from scratch since the most most of the learned parameters are taken directly from the pre-trained model
a much smaller number of parameters needs to be learned during fine-tuning so transfer learning allows certain
tasks to be toggled and take less time with less effort and at a lower cost in practice though this only works
well when people share their pre-trained models lucky for us the culture machine learning research nowadays has given
research to a rich open source model ecosystem it's become commonplace for
well-resourced industry and academic researchers to release their model checkpoints when their state-of-the-art or sota work
gets accepted into into a top tier conference typically this code is released in the form of github repositories with extensive
how-to guides well-documented readmes and from my experience they're generally very well maintained with lots of attention being
paid to open issues and bug reports oftentimes this allows other researchers
and grad students to easily reproduce figures from the initial papers and potentially use these models in source code as a starting point for
their own research projects this and this process plays out in the loop ensuring a healthy
self-reinforcing model supply chain and ultimately a quicker pace of scientific innovation
however while this emergent model sharing ecosystem beneficially lowers the barrier to entry for non-experts it
also gives a leg up to those seeking to leverage open source models for malicious purposes but just how much has this barrier to
entry been lowered though as a starting point and hopefully this statement shouldn't be too controversial
in security and especially the malware space we know that adversaries use open source
tools like cobalt strike empire powershell and mimikats the same concept holds for synthetic media
generation if there are tools out there that make this easier to do it's safe to assume that those tools will be used
to put this into perspective we experimented with a pre-trained natural language processing neural net called generative
pre-trained transformer or gpt-2 a pre-trained computer vision neural net called stylegan2
and a pre-trained text-to-speech neural net called speaker verification to text-to-speech synthesizer
or sv2 tts on the right-hand side you'll see a chart showing these three networks that we'll dive deeper into on upcoming
slides followed by the self-reported resources that the authors used in order to develop their respective
models so what's striking about these figures if and when they were available is that
the thousands of dollars weeks or months of time sheer training data set sizes and large
gpu clusters puts pre-training well out of the reach of script kitties and other low-resourced adversaries style gan 2's
authors went above and beyond by more realistically quantifying research sutures from the id inception all the way to the open source
release figures that might give even well-resourced adversaries some pause
in comparison the fine-tuning experiments which i'll go into next can be each done in a fraction of the
time cost data size compute and flops compared to these pre-training numbers
whether it's a cloud cloud-hosted notebook with gpu access like google collab pro or an aws p3 instance reservation for
just a single day we're talking on the order of just tens of dollars to fine tune one of these models
skill wise fine tuning is not necessarily trivial but it's also not brain surgery authors or other open source
contributors often release additional code and tutorials for how to fine tune so that all you really need to have is
some working knowledge of python to do this furthermore it's important to point out that each of these models were released
just within the last year so our demonstration should be seen through the lens of the present however open source trends we point out
here are accelerating and the bar for generating credible content will likely lower even further in the years to come
so our first proof of concept will be in the image domain where we'll demonstrate how to fine-tune stylegam2
in order to generate custom portraits to impersonate a targeted individual we'll start with a brief overview of
stylegen2 which like its predecessor stylegan is architected as a generative adversarial neural network organ
gans consists of two underlying networks that are pit against each other hence adversarial a generator which generates new
instances of data and a discriminator which evaluates these instances for authenticity by deciding whether each
one belongs to the actual training data set or not in this way the gant can synthesize indistinguishably fake images
based on a training data set which for the open source version of stylegan 2 used here was
flickr faces high quality or ffhq a set of 70 000 human faces that are
diverse in terms of age ethnicity and image background but also in terms of the presence of accessories
like glasses earrings and hats so if you generate images from this off-the-shelf pre-trained model
you get results that look like this alternatively you can visit this now infamous website that will generate a
new sample from the pre-trained model every time you refresh the page in either case these images are not
present in style gain 2's original training set but are completely fabricated from the generative model
these people in fact do not nor never have existed pre-trained style gan 2 outputs random
high quality and highly diverse images that appear in a similar orientation as the images that it was pre-trained on
but it can also be fine-tuned on private data sets to generate outputs for a custom task
that i as a consumer of their open source model am in control of in this example we've downloaded a few
hundred images of tom hanks from an online image search engine run them through an automated cropping tool
called auto crop so that each of them are fee centered and 512 by 512 pixels as required by the
pre-trained model and simply continue training style gain 2 by pointing it at this new smaller data set
using a slightly slightly smaller learning rate after less than a day of training on a single gpu we then generated outputs
from the fine-tune model using a ready-to-use script available from the original repo the three images you're seeing of mr
hanks on the right are fake they're generated from our fine-tuned model you could see that they exhibit a high
level of resemblance to mr hanks and in theory we could collect cropped images from any target of our choosing
and perform the same exercise to generate arbitrarily many fake images of them in summary we can cheaply generate fake
portraits belonging to a target of our choice at scale from freely available images in them on the internet
our second perfect concept will be in the audio domain where we'll demonstrate how to fine-tune sv2 tts
in order to generate custom voices from arbitrary text to impersonate a targeted individual
sp2 tts is a complex three-stage model that's capable of performing voice cloning
or text-to-speech from arbitrary text inputs to captured reference speech in real
time so how does this system work it's comprised of three underlying networks
first the speaker encoder is trained on thousands of speakers in order to learn an abstract representation of human
speech and squeeze it into a compressed embedding of floating point values then the synthesizer which is based on
google's tacotron 2 takes texas input and returns a male spectrogram which is a numerical
representation of an individual's voice lastly the vocoder which is based on google's
wavenet takes the mouse spectrogram and converts it into an output waveform that we can actually listen to
to emphasize how much data it took for this model to learn useful representations the tools authors state that it was
pre-trained in over 2 500 audios of hours of audio from over 8 500 individual speakers
which is just a herculean task for the people involved in that dataset collection so to demonstrate the kind of output
that pre-trained sv-22gs model can generate i'll let it explain itself using custom input text spoken by
an existing voice from their training dataset
is cloning using an open source model we're using a pre-trained speaker encoder and providing custom input text
in the upper right white box the pre-trained speaker encoder creates a vector representation of the speaker's
voice these embeddings can be seen in the lower left heat maps the voice embeddings and text
embeddings are combined by a synthesizer to produce the mil spectrograms in the lower right hand corner lastly a vocoder
takes these spectrograms and generates an audio waveform which you are hearing right now
so the pre-trained sv2 tts can be used to generate speech using arbitrary text from one of a few
hundred or so voices one on which we demonstrated in the last slide it can also be fine-tuned to
generate speech in an arbitrary voice using arbitrary text all we need to do is collect some audio
samples which are freely available to record via the internet load up a few of the resulting m4a files
and use the pre-trained sv2 tts model as a feature extractor to synthesize new speech waveforms
listen to a snippet of one of those m4a samples of tom hanks that we used for fine tuning now
so examples of mr hanks like that one and using them as new inputs i'll demonstrate the
result of fine-tuning on a few texts that were chosen by us to resemble commentary that is that
is representative of some broader i o themes it demonstrates that we have a common enemy but i would not count on this
relationship to go beyond that this regime has shown it will not hesitate to burden good relations for its own financial gain
the leaked documents clearly show that the foreign minister is corrupt and that he has misdirected funds
the intelligence services have indicated that these anti-government protests have been organized by foreign entities
they are bent on stirring up trouble and causing harm to the people of our country
you'll notice that the timber of the voice is very similar to mr hanks in that it's able to synthesize tom's voice from custom text
neither the text nor the voices have been explicitly contained in any of the original training data sets in principle i could generate such cell
phone quality speech audio from arbitrary targets as long as i could acquire audio or video files of them on the internet
and then make that speaker dictate from arbitrary custom text that i control it's also worth noting that i don't even
need gpu to do this the pre-trained model was fine-tuned locally using my laptop's own cpu course
which also suggests that that quality improvements are possible as well
our last proof of concept will be in the text domain where we'll generate we'll demonstrate how to fine-tune gpt2 in order to
generate custom social media posts reflecting narratives stemming from a social media i o campaign
gpt2 is an open source neural network that was trained on the causal language modeling task the objective here is to predict the
next word in a sentence from previous context meaning that a trained model ends up being capable of language generation
if the model can predict the next word accurately it can be used in turn to predict the following word and then so on and so forth until
eventually the model produces fully coherent sentences and paragraphs in terms of architectures which you can
see here on the right side of the slide transformers use attention to decrease the time required to train on enormous
data sets they also tend to model lengthy text and scale better than previous generations of feed-forward and recurrent neural
networks again to emphasize the sheer amount of trading data this thing was pre-trained on
gbt-2's training data set consisted of over 40 gigabytes of internet text data extracted from over 8 million reputable
web pages based on high reddit karma an example of gpt2's output generation
is pictured here for predictions primed by the phase it's disgraceful that the passage
displays relatively formal grammar punctuation and structure that corresponds to the text present within their original
data set i won't read through the entire passage now but you can visit our blog post at the link below for more
technical details or download this slide deck for closer inspection overall though the content is prosaic sets a scene up
between a few different people and includes dialogue of their interactions in a consistent and logical faction
so to make gpt2's output text appear more more like social media posts with their shorter length
informal grammar erratic punctuation and syntactic works like hashtags and emojis
we fine-tuned it on a new language modeling task using additional training data this data consisted of open source
social media posts from accounts operated by russia's famed internet research agency or ira troll factory for fine tuning
we simply process social media posts from these open source data sets through the pre-trained model whose
activations were then fed through adjustable weights into a linear output layer these fine-tuned text generations are
formatted like something we might expect to encounter scrolling through social media they're short yet biting express
certainty and outrage regarding hot button political issues and contain emphases like an exclamation
point they also contain idiosyncrasies like hashtags and emojis that positionally manifest at the end of the
generated text depicting a semantic style regularly exhibited by actual users
so now that i've gone over some background and technical proof of concepts for how to leverage fine-tuning of open source neural networks for
customizable purposes i'll hand it over to lee to show you how these capabilities can in turn be
leveraged for il campaigns hi everyone once again my name is lee
foster and i run the information operations analysis team at fireeye which is dedicated to identifying and
tracking state-backed cyber-driven influence campaigns online now that phil has detailed the various
technical aspects of synthetic media generation and demonstrated the ease with which
existing models can be fine-tuned for specialist use cases i'm going to explore the risks that such
capabilities present in the information operation space now the misuse of synthetic media for io
has been hotly debated in various circles for a few years now some argue it will change the game to
such an extent that it will become difficult to ascertain whether anything we consume online is true or false
others argue that the threat is way overblown and that there are much simpler yet still effective influence and manipulation techniques
that negate the need for threat actors to even entertain the use of synthetic generation
however the majority of such debates are often overly narrow over prioritizing or focusing only on
deep fake videos without sufficiently taking into account other types of synthetic media that are easier to produce from a
technical standpoint and can be more readily integrated into the types of i o campaigns my team identifies daily
so what kinds of techniques do we see io actors use currently they are numerous and while i don't have
time to touch them more than a tiny proportion it's useful to highlight a few current tactics that we've observed that would
be particularly conducive to leveraging synthetic media last year for example my team uncovered
an influence campaign we termed distinguished impersonator which we assess is being conducted in support of iranian political interests
one prominent campaign tactic involves fabricating journalists personas and reaching out to real world experts
and political figures to disingenuously solicit audio and video interviews that advance an iranian political agenda
the link at the bottom of the slide here directs to some of our public reporting on this campaign if you're interested in
more detail another common tactic we see is the development of cross-platform online personas that are used to infiltrate
target groups or disseminate fabricated content to specific audiences there are many many examples of such
activity out there perhaps most famously the russian internet research agency that phil mentioned earlier
however another recent example is the ghostwriter campaign that my team has uncovered a campaign that has leveraged website
compromises and used multiple well-developed personas to disseminate fabricated content such as falsified correspondence of
officials in eastern europe in support of russian security interests another extremely common tactic is the
use of large networks of inauthentic social media accounts pertaining pretending to be random unaffiliated
individuals which are then used to amplify political narratives across platforms and geographies
one prominent recent example of this are the networks we have identified operating on western social media
platforms pushing pro-china narratives around issues such as democracy protests in hong kong
and the covet 19 pandemic the link at the bottom of this slide directs to a presentation me and a colleague gave
on some of this activity last year and finally other very common techniques
include the use of appropriated photos of real individuals to backstop false personas and the repeated use of identical text
on social media to astroturf political commentary synthetic media has real potential to
exacerbate the use and effectiveness of these tactics for example we already regularly
observed the use of artificially generated profile photos for inauthentic social media accounts and false personas but we can readily
envision an escalation of this tactic in which convincing personas are created using artificially generated profile
photos trained on images of real people from a target group or geography that correspond to say a particular
minority group and are used to instigate political conflict or incite animosity and violence
the use of synthetically generated audio interviews in a campaign similar to the pro iran distinguished impersonator
campaign i mentioned previously trained on a real political expert's voice would lower an
actor's burden by removing the need for them to engage in direct outreach to real people which would also make attribution more
difficult for investigators by reducing available leads such as contact details and modes of communication between the
actor and target and synthetic media would drastically lower the barriers to actors
seeking to disseminate diverse text-based content at scale reducing the investment
required to manually create a large corpus of content and the need to repeatedly reuse
snippets of identical text the unifying finding our theme behind
all these example use cases is that they would materially help thread actors scale campaigns
at low cost and better evade detection fine-tuning in particular presents a
problem for blue teams as it allows threat actors to evade classifiers and detection models that are built for
pre-trained outputs this is worrisome as as a would-be threat actor my fine-tuning data sets
are private and unknown to the defender at test time to illustrate this we perform detection
experiments in the text domain using gpt2 after releasing gpt2 openai released
source code and a pre-trained classifier called roberta which does not share the same architecture or tokenizer as gpt2
but could reliably discriminate between gpt2's own output generations and its original training data of high karma reddit posts
we use roberta first to verify their findings that one can reliably differentiate between fabricated gpt2
generated text and the authentic gpt2 training data set which is shown by the blue bars in the
plots on the right the first plot shows the scores returned by the detection model on text generated
by the pre-trained gpt-2 model the fact that the distribution is skewed all the way towards the right
close to one means the detection model with a classification threshold of 0.5
can easily classify the generations as fake this results in an accuracy score of over 97 for the detection model
as shown in the lower right plot however when we perform the same exercise using the pre-trained classifier to try to
differentiate our fine-tuned io generations that feel detailed earlier the accuracy dipped to
around 78 as the distribution of scores output by the classifier for these fine-tuned
generations shifts closer to chance i8.5 as shown in the red in the top right plot
so if thread actors were to fine-tune on a custom data set they themselves collated this would
present a problematic asymmetry between the data used to create the synthetic generations and the data with which
blue teams would have access to or knowledge of with which to build a commensurate detection model
so as mentioned previously we already frequently see i o campaigns use synthetically generated profile
photos for inauthentic accounts on social media and here are some examples of recent
intelligence reports on i o activity my team has detected that i screenshotted to give you a sense
of both the scale and diversity of this current use case so we've seen the use of synthetic profile images in
the pro china networks that i mentioned previously in a recent operation that appeared designed to
support government officials in a region of argentina to backstop a fabricated journalist
persona that was used to amplify awareness of the defacement of a news agency's twitter account in kuwait
and in a social media operation that promoted cuban government political interests
and this is what that looks like in practice along with some of the markers of inauthenticity that often clue us
into the images being artificially generated you can see in these examples from one of the pro-china networks the common
format of a closely cropped headshot with a blurred background anomalies around the ears and neck and
difficulties with fully rendering glasses phantom hair strings being generated outside a credible area
common issues with the rendering of earrings and shoulders as you can see in this image that was used in the argentina related activity
set and hilariously in in these last two examples the operators behind the pro cuba
network didn't even bother to crop out the text placed by the this person does not exist at all stating that the images were generated
with style again prior to use now one of the criticisms that is
regularly leveled at concerns about the misuse of synthetic media is the high level of effort required on
the part of malicious actors however it is important to note that in many cases the difficult technical work
has already been done by organizations and individuals who have developed and released either to use applications and services
or source code that performs generations for a number of non-malicious motivations including hobbyism i.e personal learning
or simply for the fun of it an ethos of the open sharing of technical research
and direct commercial applications for marketing and advertising corporate communications and training
materials and even for the creation of assets in video games and other consumable media
synthetic media as a service is particularly worrisome as it is important to note that we have
already seen actors outsource the organization and conduct of specific influence campaigns
to public relations firms and other organizations that possess a nuanced understanding of
how to target audiences and create engaging content for example facebook has announced
multiple takedowns of accounts and pages on their platforms engaging in foreign interference that were operated by pr firms
last month they removed assets operated by a canada-based firm but engaged in election-related
influence activity in south america and in may removed assets operated by a tunisia-based firm
that poses locals and independent news outlets in sub-saharan africa it does not take much for io actors to
make a similar leap to the use of commercial providers of synthetic media generation to augment their campaigns and further
bypass the technological barriers to entry beyond the use of transfer learning that phil detailed earlier
indeed the the adoption of commercial outsourcing would provide numerous benefits to i o actors
including providing multiple avenues for operational deployment which would reduce direct ties back to
sponsors and make campaign attribution more difficult for investigators increasing the diversity and specialization of both
assets and content by drawing on external expertise lowering the investment and expertise required by
a sponsor themselves to partake in synthetic media augmented io and adding multiple layers of anonymity
and plausible deniability against accusations of responsibility for any particular campaign
so what should we take away from everything that phil and i have discussed throughout this talk first and perhaps
obviously it highlights the need for the research community to focus attention on the development of technical detection
and mitigation capabilities there are already some organizations focused on this mission and multiple
avenues of research that can and should be pursued these include statistical and machine learning approaches to detecting
synthetic media as well as the identification of fingerprints and forensic indicators such as text-based grammatical and
image-based positional indicators that can be detected both manually and in automated ways
other avenues of effort focus on the content authentication side of the challenge developing ways of allowing producers to
verify mark or sign legitimate content for example through the insertion of trackable metadata
at the content generation stage and similarly ways for the developers of synthetic generation tools to
watermark those tools is output and then of course there are hotly debated policy considerations around
content moderation social media account registration authentication and fact checking that are currently nowhere close to being resolved
technical approaches to the challenge alone won't suffice however and there's the human aspect to all of this
which we've tagged patching human perception this includes the importance of building a community-wide
approach to mitigating the human impacts of synthetic media augmented io and ensuring communities of researchers
coalesce around approaches to overcoming the challenges of detection threat modeling how synthetic media may
be used in future i o campaigns and encouraging commercial providers of synthetic generation tools to
acknowledge the potential for their abuse by threat actors and verifying customer use cases prior
to service provision indeed the sankey diagram here is the output of an exercise we did in which we
surveyed the offerings of some current commercial providers of synthetic media generation services
which we define as those that explicitly offer paid services instead of or in addition to free tools
looking at image video and voice generation offerings we asked two questions what specific use
cases do these providers market themselves towards and do they explicitly acknowledge the potential for misuse of
their services through any kind of ethics statement of the 14 companies we looked at less
than half had any kind of ethics statement perhaps equally if not more concerning
some firms did not even feign to market themselves to any particular use case whatsoever effectively leaving it up to end users
to determine the purposes their synthetic generations might even be used for only a couple of companies specifically
in the voice generation space explicitly stated that they verify and sign off on their customers as end use
cases before agreeing to provide services and there also remains the need for
raising awareness and educating consumers of online content about the risks of synthetic media in a
responsible manner that doesn't misrepresent the threat as well as developing legal and regulatory approaches to dealing with
information operations and synthetic media the final takeaway we want to raise is
that we are really in the calm before the storm stage of synthetic media's use in information operations as phil
highlighted these capabilities continue to become cheaper both monetarily and in terms of computing power required
easier more pervasive and outputs ever more credible and there are numerous trends that risk
further escalation of threat the amount of effort required to fine-tune existing models or train new
models will continue to decrease multimodal content will likely one day incorporate synthetically generated text
images and audio in single pieces of content image generation capabilities and even
commercial services are already moving beyond merely headshots and facial generations to full body shots
and advanced video generations and end users will enjoy increasing control over and ease of content
generation both through being able to steer generations towards particular attributes at more granular levels
and by being able to leverage an increasing amount of low code or no code applications for content creation and
one really important factor to keep in mind is user susceptibility to misleading content
some criticize the threat of synthetic media as being overblown because there are still telltale signs of inauthenticity in contemporary
synthetic generations but even if we set aside all the trends i just mentioned it
is critical for us to acknowledge that synthetic generations don't need to be overwhelmingly credible to have that
desired effect people are accustomed to consuming short authoritative error-riddled social media text at speed
without dwelling too much on its linguistic features or origin they are accustomed to consuming poor
quality audio and video snippets and most users are unlikely to give a twitter's a twitter account's profile
image more than a cursory glance as they scroll through their feed and ingest the written content at rapid speed all
of this points to a crucial consideration the quality bar does not need to be particularly high when it comes to
synthetic generations it only needs to remain good enough for a majority of users to not question
it in a world characterized by high speed high volume information consumption
so to summarize fine tuning for generative impersonation in the text image and audio domains can be performed
by non-experts and it can be weaponized for offensive social media driven information operations detection attribution and
response is challenging in scenarios where actors can anonymously generate and distribute credible fake content using proprietary
training data sets and we as a community can and should help ai researchers policy makers and
other stakeholders mitigate the harmful effects of open source models
we'd like to thank you for your time today and look forward to answering your questions
